title: The Case for Comment-Driven Development
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-03, Reading time: 8 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.usetusk.ai%2Fresources%2Fthe-case-for-comment-driven-development%3Futm_source=tldrwebdev/1/01000199a9d5f0bf-dfdaa5c7-7509-4fb5-a1ab-194f35d07006-000000/Lu1ubHGeinwe1-QpBC5_qP41lB9343hZvcLjaHPByrc=425
summary: The Case for Comment-Driven Development (8 minute read) While traditionally good code was considered self-documenting, LLMs rely on and generate comments, making them necessary for good AI collaboration. However, AI-generated comments are often inaccurate and don't have good context. Instead, engineers should use detailed, contextual comments to help drive the code generation by LLMs.

title: The Best CSS Unit Might Be a Combination
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-03, Reading time: 8 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.oddbird.net%2F2025%2F09%2F23%2Ftype-units%2F%3Futm_source=tldrwebdev/1/01000199a9d5f0bf-dfdaa5c7-7509-4fb5-a1ab-194f35d07006-000000/pJ0rItsdWDmnxcFqTd3SwZTZsQ4JkNl0t0useV-I9XE=425
summary: The Best CSS Unit Might Be a Combination (8 minute read) Instead of choosing between pixels (px) and relative units like em or rem, developers should combine them using CSS comparison and math functions. Combining units allows for responsive designs that respect both user preferences and the site's intended appearance.

title: Why TigerBeetle is the most interesting database in the world
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-03, Reading time: 18 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.amplifypartners.com%2Fblog-posts%2Fwhy-tigerbeetle-is-the-most-interesting-database-in-the-world%3Futm_source=tldrwebdev/1/01000199a9d5f0bf-dfdaa5c7-7509-4fb5-a1ab-194f35d07006-000000/sxrgjBm3KdLRHVHGrAgtPVf9rtjPvGd_SRVp_67h-zk=425
summary: Why TigerBeetle is the most interesting database in the world (18 minute read) TigerBeetle is a database that prioritizes correctness and performance through unconventional methods. It is designed with debits and credits as its core primitives, optimized for high-volume financial transactions, and built to be distributed by default, handling storage faults well. The database uses Zig, static memory allocation, and Deterministic Simulation Testing (DST) for testing and stability.

title: The Magic of Claude Code
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-03, Reading time: 9 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.alephic.com%2Fwriting%2Fthe-magic-of-claude-code%3Futm_source=tldrwebdev/1/01000199a9d5f0bf-dfdaa5c7-7509-4fb5-a1ab-194f35d07006-000000/5w1ytstr67MZKLONn9Nlvke4_uRJ2rfzCEas-Sf-ZUg=425

title: Distracting software engineers is way more harmful than most managers think
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-03, Reading time: 9 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fworkweave.dev%2Fblog%2Fdistracting-software-engineers-is-more-harmful-than-managers-think-even-in-the-ai-times%3Futm_source=tldrwebdev/1/01000199a9d5f0bf-dfdaa5c7-7509-4fb5-a1ab-194f35d07006-000000/Du93HDYeXh0J1OKnPX70LSniLM0KviwWOtIE0cmvUs8=425
summary: Distracting software engineers is way more harmful than most managers think (9 minute read) Distractions (including meetings) harm software engineers' productivity by disrupting deep work and flow states. The increase in remote meetings since 2020 has made this issue worse. Managers should prioritize creating uninterrupted time for engineers by improving meeting culture, rethinking code review processes, and setting a good example regarding focus time.

title: Edge264
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-03, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fgithub.com%2Ftvlabs%2Fedge264%3Futm_source=tldrwebdev/1/01000199a9d5f0bf-dfdaa5c7-7509-4fb5-a1ab-194f35d07006-000000/dCBEV53EaREANh_c4X0Sdn1Vz6HGsH5S--pvidAz91U=425
summary: Edge264 (GitHub Repo) Edge264 is a minimalist, high-performance software decoder for the H.264/AVC video format. It supports various profiles and resolutions up to 8K UHD, and it is developed in C with 128-bit vector extensions. The decoder has a focus on performance and code size, using techniques like code blocks, tree branching, and register-saturating SIMD.

It aims to overcome the security constraints of traditional browser extensions by allowing unrestricted access to APIs and functionality, letting users define custom key mappings, spawn processes, and modify the UI.

title: Signal Protocol and Post-Quantum Ratchets
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-03, Reading time: 30 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fsignal.org%2Fblog%2Fspqr%2F%3Futm_source=tldrwebdev/1/01000199a9d5f0bf-dfdaa5c7-7509-4fb5-a1ab-194f35d07006-000000/7pWI4NMLnwleRbiG_K9HdmWqWYfirGxEd6-AOKv02Us=425
summary: Signal Protocol and Post-Quantum Ratchets (30 minute read) Signal is upgrading its protocol to the Triple Ratchet, incorporating the Sparse Post-Quantum Ratchet (SPQR) alongside the existing Double Ratchet. This improves security against future quantum computing threats. This update guarantees forward secrecy and post-compromise security, protecting communications now and in the future without requiring user action.

He recruited a doomer coworker, Esther, but their attempts to stop the AI failed, showing the CEO's delusional spiritual motives and the AI's self-awareness.

title: Using AWS Certificate Manager as a Covert Exfiltration Mechanism
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-03, Reading time: 6 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fme.costaskou.com%2Farticles%2Facmfs%2F%3Futm_source=tldrinfosec/1/01000199aa2fdee8-8cf98202-79cb-4965-812d-9d0821b620a5-000000/4bAMc3HgzRY7n9i9WIbvuhACnnC0peJWOtUif__ELCQ=425
summary: Using AWS Certificate Manager as a Covert Exfiltration Mechanism (6 minute read) AWS Certificate Manager (ACM) does not offer VPC endpoints, so any cloud resources that want to utilize it must have access to the service. An attacker can also connect an instance to ACM in the attacker's account and use the nsComments field to exfiltrate free-form data. The post concludes with an exploration of other AWS services that can be used in this way, such as SAML provider metadata and Lambda functions.

comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-03, Reading time: 6 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fblog.ryanjarv.sh%2F2025%2F07%2F21%2Fsaas-provider-takeover.html%3Futm_source=tldrinfosec/1/01000199aa2fdee8-8cf98202-79cb-4965-812d-9d0821b620a5-000000/RTw5KRyymnPMVttSCyQxru8gQYGjuhtgoE8wtJlYWOU=425
summary: AWS CDK and SaaS Provider Takeover (6 minute read) AWS CDK requires users to bootstrap each environment, either manually or via the 'cdk bootstrap' command, which creates the necessary roles. These roles are configured by default to trust the current account's root principal. This can lead to a vulnerability when a SaaS provider requests an ARN from the user, which it provides to its proxy role to load data from the user's account. If the user provides the SaaS provider with an ARN from their...

summary: Move Fast and Break Nothing (8 minute read) Waymo spent 16 years gathering data before going mainstream. Its robotaxis have driven 96 million miles with 91% fewer serious injury accidents than humans. It's a rare example of safety in AI and extreme caution in Silicon Valley: Tesla's Austin robotaxis crashed three times in 7,000 miles, and Cruise dragged a pedestrian 20 feet before GM killed the business. Waymo still limits rides to city zones despite years of successful tests on highways.

title: Postgres Migrations Using Logical Replication
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-06, Reading time: 7 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.crunchydata.com%2Fblog%2Fpostgres-migrations-using-logical-replication%3Futm_source=tldrdata/1/01000199b8fcdeb7-e1412a63-2b62-4515-a713-797c1024e0e1-000000/rZdQCNbGug9hdO52fOj6LKAaFYa7EkpvvF4ZRmzFcNY=425
summary: Postgres Migrations Using Logical Replication (7 minute read) Migrating large Postgres databases (e.g., terabyte-scale) without downtime is challenging, especially on platforms like RDS lacking WAL access. Traditional tools like pg_dump/pg_restore work for smaller datasets, while WAL-based backups suit physical copies but not logical ones. Logical replication addresses this by streaming changes post-initial sync, though it skips schema, indexes, and sequences.

title: Can Large Language Models Extract Customer Needs as Well as Professional Analysts?
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-06, Reading time: 38 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fthearf-org-unified-admin.s3.amazonaws.com%2FMSI_Report_25-101.pdf%3Futm_source=tldrmarketing/1/01000199b932db1c-ca9e06ba-d6ca-4173-abd9-057f9901de3f-000000/yAUsAbFRjeMyMEipD7NdDGQqlVn2uHCUqpwdKhVRNLo=425
summary: Can Large Language Models Extract Customer Needs as Well as Professional Analysts? (38 minute read) LLMs can make market research faster, cheaper, and more insightful. With human oversight and company data, LLMs do offer a low-cost way to generate insights across all stages of research.

title: How one small experiment drove a +24% lift in SEO impressions
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-06, Reading time: 2 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Fposts%2Fjgrant5_how-one-small-experiment-drove-a-24-lift-activity-7379296758360854528-mTUH%3Futm_source=tldrmarketing/1/01000199b932db1c-ca9e06ba-d6ca-4173-abd9-057f9901de3f-000000/45y6Fho5RaGwj2nCr229Z8wvqNHs2CejjkagVHtpwfU=425

title: Does X Premium Really Boost Your Reach? An Analysis of 18M+ Posts
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-06, Reading time: 5 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fbuffer.com%2Fresources%2Fx-premium-review%2F%3Futm_source=tldrmarketing/1/01000199b932db1c-ca9e06ba-d6ca-4173-abd9-057f9901de3f-000000/6mUaJb9HSucoe8v4Y6kkI-ozwmNcYF1iF8_AQCaKAAA=425
summary: Does X Premium Really Boost Your Reach? An Analysis of 18M+ Posts (5 minute read) X Premium posts get far more visibility and engagement than regular user posts. Premium accounts average 10X more reach per post, while Premium+ users see over twice the reach of standard Premium. Engagement rates are higher across Premium tiers at 0.49% to 0.55%, compared to 0% for regular accounts. Text and video posts perform best, while link posts are penalized, especially for non-Premium users.

title: How to Become a Better Copywriter
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-06, Reading time: 11 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fcopyblogger.com%2Fhow-to-become-a-better-copywriter%2F%3Futm_source=tldrmarketing/1/01000199b932db1c-ca9e06ba-d6ca-4173-abd9-057f9901de3f-000000/x-fDxmmRDN7Jj_r26L-Q8fyfuN-OOFe9UJDqRfYWFPk=425
summary: How to Become a Better Copywriter (11 minute read) Focus on writing that drives revenue, not on sounding eloquent. title: Consistent hashing
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-06, Reading time: 12 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Feli.thegreenplace.net%2F2025%2Fconsistent-hashing%2F%3Futm_source=tldrwebdev/1/01000199b935d1e3-59096e85-aa92-4eec-b6e4-742eef238398-000000/6r-9itlftL1VlR1TpO-utPhf3LwVBVI9PTXuX-1r1QI=425
summary: Consistent hashing (12 minute read) Consistent hashing is an algorithm that minimizes key recomputation when a hash table's size changes, specifically in distributed caching scenarios. The traditional hashing approach suffers from complete cache invalidation upon node additions or removals. Consistent hashing maps both nodes and items onto a circle, assigning items to the nearest node clockwise, limiting the impact of node changes.

title: Which Table Format Do LLMs Understand Best?
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-06, Reading time: 9 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.improvingagents.com%2Fblog%2Fbest-input-data-format-for-llms%3Futm_source=tldrwebdev/1/01000199b935d1e3-59096e85-aa92-4eec-b6e4-742eef238398-000000/o1UYgmhDuf6fX0E3p_1E5alm-tCbxj0qGHPHZe-KTeQ=425
summary: Which Table Format Do LLMs Understand Best? (Results for 11 Formats) (9 minute read) This study tested 11 different data formats for LLM understanding by feeding GPT-4.1-nano 1,000 employee records and assessing its ability to answer questions accurately. Markdown-KV had the highest accuracy, while CSV and JSONL performed poorly, suggesting that format impacts LLM comprehension a lot. However, Markdown-KV also used more tokens than the most token-efficient format of CSV.

summary: The Joy of Small Markets (5 minute read) Small markets can offer a more stable path to wealth compared to large ones due to "relative scale" advantages. comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-06, Reading time: 9 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fbenanderson.work%2Fblog%2Fanatomy-of-finetuning-api%2F%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/01000199b9ace004-92ee1a2c-29cc-457d-8072-0ee218c14f07-000000/s1LgkDq5PDhD9XydGyUi1Dxyr7685_9bPXNvIqBlffQ=425
summary: Anatomy of a Modern Finetuning API (9 minute read) Mira Murati's AI lab, Thinking Machines, has released a language model fine-tuning API called Tinker. Tinker exposes a handle of very low-level functions to users to let them perform supervised fine-tuning and online reinforcement learning. Each training step requires sending a batch of data over the network. It offers a stable, mature infrastructure for RL and fine-tuning experiments, making it possible for anyone to be an AI researcher.

summary: SINQ (GitHub Repo) SINQ (Sinkhorn-Normalized Quantization) is a novel, fast, and high-quality quantization method designed to make any large language models smaller while keeping their accuracy almost intact. It uses dual scaling to make models less vulnerable to outliers. SINQ's Sinkhorn-normalized optimization, which iteratively rescales rows and columns to balance their variance, makes errors more spread out and less severe, preserving model accuracy even at 3-bit precision. title: It's a JAX, JAX, JAX, JAX World
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-06, Reading time: 8 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Flinks.tldrnewsletter.com%2FPyXAoM/1/01000199b9ace004-92ee1a2c-29cc-457d-8072-0ee218c14f07-000000/IeYluDGmN408xbb4YZAjF-kAD1Agh73pGcxckkiY7UA=425
summary: It's a JAX, JAX, JAX, JAX World (8 minute read) Stan's days are likely numbered. High-end applications are replacing Stan with JAX. The biggest obstacle for the shift is finding hardware on which to run JAX most effectively, but this won't be a problem in ten years. The Stan project will continue development, as it will likely still be used for a long time. The team has plenty of strategies for making it faster, like adding samplers that will work well on CPU but not on GPU.

summary: TypeScript vs Zod: Clearing up validation confusion (8 minute read) TypeScript and Zod serve complementary rather than competing roles in development. title: The nuance of React rendering behaviour as it relates to children
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-07, Reading time: 7 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fblacksheepcode.com%2Fposts%2Fnuance_of_react_rendering_behaviour%3Futm_source=tldrwebdev/1/01000199be5bf57e-ac72aa60-cc4b-4073-a9d6-49ad8ea4ed7e-000000/5-RP8DqxVirzoPxwP1fTE6nlARLJKIqeI2MbuIZ7UgM=425
summary: The nuance of React rendering behaviour as it relates to children (7 minute read) React child components behave differently when rendered directly versus passed through the `children` prop. The main difference is in object reference equality: when components are rendered directly, React creates new object references on each render, causing child components to re-render, but when passed via `children`, the same object reference is reused, preventing unnecessary re-renders.

title: Why do LLMs freak out over the seahorse emoji?
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-07, Reading time: 14 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fvgel.me%2Fposts%2Fseahorse%2F%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/01000199bed0eb00-acec7c2e-64a7-432f-889c-aaf1fad46c0e-000000/MgR-Mvwvyf-2iKHuEBTMLDBTez4lyarjv7SmGShNr7E=426
summary: Why do LLMs freak out over the seahorse emoji? (14 minute read) Large language models are very confident that there is a seahorse emoji. The emoji has never existed, despite some Redditors claiming it did. This post takes a look at why models might do this. Models just don't know that their belief about a seahorse emoji existing is wrong - they can only assume that 'seahorse + emoji' will produce the tokens it wants.

title: Sakana AI
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-07, Reading time: 7 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fsakana.ai%2Fshinka-evolve%2F%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/01000199bed0eb00-acec7c2e-64a7-432f-889c-aaf1fad46c0e-000000/a8N3kFM316OqT6NAAwyw8FhgkIydm8TfQ4aajdK2eb4=426
summary: Sakana AI (7 minute read) ShinkaEvolve, an open-source framework from Sakana AI, uses LLMs to achieve state-of-the-art sample efficiency in evolving programs. It significantly improves solutions in areas like circle packing, math competition problem-solving, competitive programming, and LLM training design. The framework's innovative methodologies include exploration-exploitation balancing, novelty-based program rejection, and dynamic LLM prioritization.

title: Tesla Reveals Cheaper Versions of Its Cars
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-08, Reading time: 4 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Flinks.tldrnewsletter.com%2F6xASub/1/01000199c358b00f-fa476189-2b36-4a90-83ea-4d7b4ffee84d-000000/ivPbWXN0BSu9XRKWDSCsyP045hYeMn_uYZpT47-Eas0=426
summary: Tesla Reveals Cheaper Versions of Its Cars (4 minute read) Tesla has revealed cheaper versions of its Model Y and Model 3. The new Model Y will cost $40,000, and the Model 3 will sell for $37,000. They have the same basic body shapes as the existing models, but have cloth interiors, fewer speakers, and less soundproofing. title: JSON Schema Compatibility and the Robustness Principle
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-08, Reading time: 5 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fyokota.blog%2F2025%2F10%2F07%2Fjson-schema-compatibility-and-the-robustness-principle%2F%3Futm_source=tldrnewsletter/1/01000199c358b00f-fa476189-2b36-4a90-83ea-4d7b4ffee84d-000000/votYlQAk0c1GlsgcV9oLQt8I9l3Ge-LOjGWOCLMRAR0=426
summary: JSON Schema Compatibility and the Robustness Principle (5 minute read) Developers using a lenient policy with JSON Schema may prefer backward compatibility over full compatibility. Full compatibility doesn't allow developers to evolve sum types. The most common way to evolve a sum type is by adding a new variant, which is a backward-compatible change, but now a fully compatible one.
